title-group.article-title: What Is Happening with Exclusive Breastfeeding in Peru?

body.p: We have read the article by Matias et al, “Determinants of exclusive breastfeeding in a cohort of primiparous periurban Peruvian mothers” conducted in our country.1 It coincides with our personal experience in clinical practice, and some outcomes match national statistics.2

According to our national statistics for 2009, in Lima, 57% of children 0-6 months old were being exclusively breastfed.3 Moreover, Matias et al selected women who were intending to exclusively breastfeed, and it has been reported in practice that women who intend to breastfeed for longer usually do.4 For these reasons, we expected the authors to report higher rates of exclusive breastfeeding; however, they found that only 35% of women continued breastfeeding their children until the sixth month. This percentage could be explained owing to methodological issues in this study.
Another matter to consider is the hospital selected for the study. A Baby-Friendly Hospital has a policy to promote exclusive breastfeeding based on the Ten Steps.

Moreover, the Baby-Friendly Hospital Initiative (BFHI) has been shown to influence the duration of breastfeeding.5 Although in the United States, the BFHI is not as efficient a strategy as others to promote exclusive breastfeeding,6 in developing countries, studies have shown that it is a useful strategy. The implementation of the BFHI is associated with a statistically significant annual increase in rates of exclusive breastfeeding.5,7 For this reason, we again ex-pected to find higher rates of exclusive breastfeeding. A possible explanation for these results could be that the hospital failed to meet the Ten Steps, for example, the high percentage of formula given to neonates during the hospital stay (29%).

This is an excellent initial study that allows us to indirectly assess compliance with the Ten Steps in the Baby-Friendly Hospitals of Lima. However, these results are far from reality in both Peru and in Lima and should not be taken as a milestone for public health measures in the area.
